Detailed Description

A WaitableEvent can be a useful thread synchronization tool when you want to allow one thread to wait for another thread to finish some work.

The following example demonstrates how to use the WaitableEvent class.

 #include <gaia/core/WaitableEvent.h>
 #include <gaia/core/WorkItem.h>
 #include <gaia/core/WorkQueue.h>
 
 using gaia::core::WaitableEvent;
 using gaia::core::WorkItem;
 using gaia::core::WorkQueue;
 
 class SimpleTask : public WorkItem
 {
 public:
     SimpleTask(WaitableEvent* waitable_event)
         : mWaitableEvent(waitable_event)
     {
     }

     virtual void run()
     {
         mWaitableEvent->signal();
     }

 private:
     WaitableEvent* const mWaitableEvent;
 };

 WaitableEvent waiter;
 WorkQueue queue("WaitableEventTest");
 
 // Run SimpleTask on another thread.
 queue.async(new SimpleTask(&waiter));
 
 // waiter will be signaled until SimpleTask::run() is executed.
 waiter.waitForever();

long gaia::core::WaitableEvent::waitForTime ( int64_t  timeoutNanosecs)

Wait up until timeoutNanosecs has passed for the event to be signaled.

Parameters:
[in]timeoutNanosecsNanoseconds to wait.
Returns:
zero on success, or non-zero if the timeoutNanosecs is expired.
